Executive Summary

Sysco Hampton Roads, Inc.



Risk Management Plan Executive Summary



RMP Executive Summary (?68.155)

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies (68.155(a))

Sysco Hampton Roads (Hampton Roads) in Suffolk, Virginia is committed to employee, public, and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by Hampton Roads' comprehensive accidental release prevention program.  It is Hampton Roads' policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  Unforeseeably, if such releases do occur, there are highly trained employees on hand to control and mitigate the effects of the releases.  The site also coordinates with the Suffolk Department of Fire & Rescue, who provides emergency response services.



The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled (?68.155(b))

There is one (1) regulated substance present at this facility.  This substance is ammonia (anhydrous).  The highest expected inventory of ammonia (anhydrous) at this facility is 21,000 pounds (rounded to two significant digits for reporting purposes). 



The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical Specific Prevention Steps (?68.155(c))

The facility has taken the following steps as required by 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part (?) 68 of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulations.  The ammonia (anhydrous) process is also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard under 29 CFR ?1910.119.  In addition, the facility is also subject to the EPA's Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act (EPCRA) Section 302 reporting requirements.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that are in place. 



Process Safety Information:

Information related to the hazards of the ammonia refrigeration system installed at the facility has been compiled.  Prior to conducting the

initial and subsequent hazard analyses, the process safety information was reviewed and utilized in identifying and mitigating recognized hazards.  The process safety information was also used in the development of the operating procedures.   



Process Hazard Analysis: 

Comprehensive studies were conducted to ensure that hazards associated with the ammonia refrigeration process were identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses was the "what-if/checklist" approach.  The studies were undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and will be revalidated at a regular interval of every five (5) years.  Any findings related to the process hazard analyses are addressed in a timely manner. 

 

Operating Procedures: 

Operating procedures are maintained at the facility.  These procedures address the various modes of operation of the ammonia refrigeration system such as initial start-up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and start-up after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process. 



Training: 

A comprehensive training program is in place to ensure that employees operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with those processes.  New employees receive basic classroom training in process operations, followed by on-the job supervision until they are deemed competent to work independently.  Refresher training on operating procedures is provided at least once every three (3) years, and more frequently as needed. 



Mechanical Integrity: 

Documented maintenance checks are conducted on process equipment to ensure proper operation.  Process equipment examined during these checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps.

Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with current training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are given specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. 



Management of Change: 

Written procedures are in place to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and processes.  Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process operations are promptly made aware of and given training to deal with the modifications. 



Pre-Startup Reviews: 

Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modification of established processes are conducted as a regular practice.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe start-up prior to placing equipment into operation. 



Compliance Audits: 

Compliance audits are conducted on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation are being implemented.  These audits are carried out at least once every three (3) years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner. 



Incident Investigation: 

Incidents that have resulted in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance are promptly investigated.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from recurring.  All incident reports are retained for a minimum of five (5) years. 



Employee Participation: 

Hampton Roads strongly believes that process safety management and accident prevention are a team effort.  Company employees are strongly urged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend i

mprovements.  In addition, the employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP regulation, including information resulting from process hazard analyses. 



Contractors: 

Contractors are utilized to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is completed. Hampton Roads has a strict policy of informing contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the process.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency notification and evacuation, should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur. 



Five-Year Accident History (?68.155(d))

Hampton Roads has not had any reportable accidents or incidents during the past five (5) years. 



Emergency Response Plan (?68.155(e))

This facility has coordinated with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and nearby responders.  This facility has its own Emergency Action Plan as well.  The Emergency Action Plan includes actions to be taken in response to accidental releases of regulated substances as well as procedures for informing the public and local response agencies of a chemical release. 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety (?68.155(f))

Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of the accidental release prevention program.  Regular reviews of the ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration system and procedures will continue.  Additionally, there will be continued notifications and pre-planning with the Suffolk Department of Fire & Rescue.
